I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) upcoming Strengthening Urban Health Services 
Project will improve quality and coverage of health services in Solomon Islands, with particular 
focus on Honiara. The following output areas are expected to be delivered under the project: (i) 
quality of services provided by NRH strengthened; (ii) primary and secondary healthcare provision 
in Honiara upgraded; and (iii) urban healthcare delivery systems improved. The total indicative 
cost for the project is $11.0 million, of which ADB is expected to finance (i) a concessional loan 
of $5.0 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, and (ii) a grant not exceeding $5.0 million 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources (Asian Development Fund). The government will provide 
support through exemption of taxes and duties and funding towards project costs (including 
through allocation of staffing for upgraded and/or new health centers), estimated at $1.0 million. 
There is no immediate co-financing partner, but discussions with bilateral partners are ongoing.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The transaction technical assistance (TRTA) of $750,000, to be implemented over a 21-
month period (January 2020–September 2021), will provide technical analysis and assessments 
to assist the government and the ADB to develop the proposed Strengthening Urban Health 
Services Project. The TRTA is justified given the scope of activities and specialist nature of skills 
required. Due diligence will be undertaken based on the proposed project design. The TRTA will 
also build the capacity of the Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) to administer the 
ensuing project, and enhance project readiness for timely implementation given ADB’s relatively 
new engagement with MHMS. The TRTA is included in the ADB’s country operations business 
plan for Solomon Islands, and the ensuing project is in the 2021 pipeline.1 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
3.  Output 1: Project scoping and design completed. This output will scope out the project 
design and activities to be undertaken throughout the investment project. It will identify specific 
measures to strengthen the functionality of the NRH, ascertain the most viable health centers to 
be upgraded and/or new sites to be constructed, and specify health systems components that 
require to be implemented in order to improve project outcomes (such as integrated referral 
pathways and workforce planning policies and guidelines). There will be careful consideration 
given to existing ADB policies including safeguards, procurement, and financial management.  
The scoping exercise will also determine the most effective sequencing of outputs and strategic 
alignment  and collaboration  with  ongoing  programs of  other development  partners, private 
institutions, and government within the context of the overall sector reform. The project design 
will also incorporate lessons learned and best practices from similar projects elsewhere in the 
Pacific, other ongoing projects in Solomon Islands, and identify the implementation modality that 
will best deliver the project outputs in accordance to the capacity of the implementing agency and 
concerned government offices involved. 
 
4.  Output 2: Project due diligence undertaken. The TRTA will support all required due 
diligence  to feed  into  and help  refine  the project design.  It  is expected to be  undertaken 
concurrently with finalization of the scope as some findings and mitigation recommendations 
might lead to adjustments in the design with financial and cost implications. Due diligence includes

economic and financial assessment, poverty, social and gender analysis, safeguards assessment 
and instruments (including climate change implications), financial management and procurement 
capacity assessment, risk assessment and management plans, cost estimates and financing plan 
and project implementation arrangements including monitoring and evaluation, among others. 
Based on these assessments and analyses, all the required project and linked documents will be 
prepared based on ADB requirements and standards, and be suitable  for compliance with 
requirements of the country systems. 
 
5.  Output 3: Support to project readiness and project management capacity of the 
implementing agency. This output will support project preparation and readiness by providing 
an advisory  role  in finalizing  the design of  the project, implementation  arrangements, and 
assessing risks and mitigation measures, in coordination with key government and other relevant 
stakeholders. This output also includes assisting the government during project start-up, such as 
preparation  for  the  recruitment of  a project management unit,  preparing  any  draft  bidding 
documents required, and providing coordination support with key government agencies and other 
relevant stakeholders as necessary. The capacity of the executing and implementing agencies 
for project preparation and implementation will also be strengthened and mechanisms to enhance 
the existing management information system will be assessed. Key activities include (i) assessing 
the  institutional  capacity  and  identifying  gaps  with  regards  to  project  preparation  and 
implementation; and (ii) organize training, capacity building exercises and activities to address 
identified gaps and areas requiring improved capacity.

7.  ADB is providing support to the Solomon Islands government to develop a comprehensive 
costed business case for the phased relocation of the NRH under separate regional technical 
assistance.2 The business case is expected to be completed in February 2020. Findings of the 
business case will inform project due diligence on economic and financial analyses, procurement, 
financial management capacity assessment, and environmental impact assessment. Proposed 
work under this TRTA take into account findings of the business case in developing specific 
outputs of the project.3  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
8.  The TRTA is estimated to cost $770,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The government will provide in-kind 
support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, data, information, and other contributions 
estimated at $20,000. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
9.  ADB will administer the TRTA. The Pacific Department’s Social Sectors and Public Sector 
Management  Division  will  select,  administer,  evaluate,  and  supervise  the  consultants,  in 
coordination with  MHMS.  The existing Senior Executive Management  Committee under the 
MHMS, consisting of the Minister, Permanent Secretary, and Under Secretaries for MHMS, will 
provide oversight for the project preparation including the technical aspects of the design. A 
project steering committee will be established as outlined in the concept paper, and will provide 
guidance once it is established. The project steering committee is envisaged to continue its 
support  during  the  implementation  of  the  project.  The  implementation  arrangements  are 
summarized in Table 2.

10.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers 
(2017, as amended from time to time).ADB will recruit one international consulting firm for an 
 
estimated 25 person-months for project design, due diligence, and project readiness and capacity 
building under the quality and cost-based selection method with a quality cost ratio of 80:20 and 
full-technical proposal. The consultants proposed to be engaged under the firm are presented in 
the linked document.4 Lump-sum payments and/or output-based contracts will be preferred. A 
national  health  advisor,  a  project  management coordinator/procurement  specialist, and  an 
environmental safeguards specialist will be recruited individually for an aggregate of 8 person-
months to support the firm.  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
11.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Solomon Islands for Strengthening Urban Health Services Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
